reporter_caption.center: FEGGETT v. CHICAGO EASTERN ILL. R. CO., 318 Ill. App. 389 (1943)

center.bold: Marshall Feggett, Appellee, v. Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad

court.center: Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District.

opinion.syllabus:
AUTOMOBILES AND MOTOR VEHICLES, §§ 207.2[fn*], 222[fn*] — evidence inaction for personal injuries sustained when plaintiff's truckwas struck at highway crossing. In action for personal injuries sustained when, in daytime, plaintiff's truck was struck by defendant's train at country highway crossing, wherein plaintiff had judgment on verdict of jury, held that, under evidence, it could not be said as matter of law that plaintiff was guilty of such want of care as to bar his right of recovery, but that evidence, which went, to question of existence of view-obstructing weeds on defendant's right of way, etc., and which was manifestly in favor of defendant, warranted granting to defendant of new trial (Ill. Rev. Stat. 1941, ch. 111 2/3, par. 62; Jones Ill. Stats. Ann. 112.083; Ill. Rev. Stat. 1941, ch. 114, par. 62; Jones Ill. Stats. Ann. 114.098).
[fn*] See Callaghan's Illinois Digest, same topic and sectionnumber.
opinion.posture:
Appeal from the Circuit Court of Vermilion county; the Hon. BEN F. ANDERSON, Judge, presiding.
Judgment reversed and remanded. Heard in this court at the February term, 1943.
opinion.opinion_text: "Not to be published in full." Opinion filed February 24, 1943; rehearing denied May 4, 1943.Page 390
